title: Moving From Hand to Hand, a Flame Arrives

body: ON oceanfront land in Brooklyn once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, the Muss Organization of Queens is moving into the third year of construction on a condominium project that is reversing the symbolism of the site -- from one linked with the past to one reflecting the possibilities the city holds for its recent immigrants and their children.
title: On Brighton Beach, a Tide of Immigrants

body: The English carol counts the 12 days of Christmas. In Provence, the Christmas number is 13, counted in desserts, symbolic nibbles to spread on the Christmas table. The number refers to Jesus and the 12 Apostles. The colors of dates and nuts represent the robes of monks. These and other sweets, including nougat, olive oil cakes, marzipan candies and
title: FOOD STUFF; And for Dessert On Christmas Day, The Box, Please

body: The subway cars on the W line snake from Queens through the heart of Manhattan and on to Brooklyn, collecting dirt and debris from thousands of riders. At the end of the line, on an elevated platform in sight of Coney Island's Ferris wheel, a dozen people in green vests sweep, scrape and swab the grime away. Transit-system employees doing the same
title: As Welfare Comes to an End, So Do the Jobs

body: In the Rockaways, sand dunes ripple past underground silos that once housed nuclear-tipped missiles. On the island where New York City maintains potter's field, prisoners bury the indigent near the foundations of former Army barracks. title: Fortress New York, Falling to Time; Across City, Vestiges of the Days of Redcoats, Rebels and Russians

body: THERE are two kinds of people this time of year: those who deck the halls and those who don't. body: A 67-year-old Brooklyn man was killed yesterday after being struck by a police car responding to an emergency call. The man, Steven Michalacos, of Sunset Park, was struck about 2 p.m. as he was crossing Fifth Avenue near 80th Street in Bay Ridge, apparently unaware of the approaching car, according to the police. He was pronounced dead at Lutheran
title: Man, 67, Dies After Being Hit by Police Car

body: Each morning, Richard Haugland of Bay Ridge goes to his gardening job at City Hall Park and looks for Liberty, a peregrine falcon he named after seeing it perched atop a park flagpole on Oct. 15. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN; Fireman's Spirit Is the Wind Beneath a Bird's Wings

body: There were 1,500 pigeons packed into traveling crates, and the Knights of Columbus taproom smelled like a barn. title: They Don't Brake for Statues; Racing Pigeons Hurry Home to Brooklyn, at 55 M.P.H.

title: Christian Arabs, Too, Are Harassed

body: A month after the terrorist attack that killed 5,000 people, destroyed the World Trade Center and shook New York to its core, many city residents say that they feel great pride and faith in their wounded metropolis. title: A NATION CHALLENGED: SURVEY; New Yorkers Are Shaken, but Resolute, After Attack

title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FAMILIES; Reports of Bombing by U.S. Intrude on Private Grief

body: It is not easy for a convicted killer to sell his story as a book. Readers distrust criminals, and publishers face the morally dubious prospect of helping someone profit from a crime. body: Phantom Railroad Q. On Hancock Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, there is a railroad crossing sign near Wyckoff Avenue, but I can't see any tracks. Why the sign? A. You need not stop or even slow down; a train hasn't crossed Hancock Street in nearly 40 years. The sign is a remnant of the New York and Manhattan Beach Railway, which was started in 1870
title: F.Y.I.

body: What does Angela Yurman know about the Battle of Brooklyn? ''Just living in Brooklyn is a battle every day,'' she says. title: Washington Fought Here; Who Knew?; On 225th Anniversary, Battle of Brooklyn Is Little-Known Chapter

body: A Revolution In Brooklyn New Yorkers may think of their city as a battlefield, but many years have passed since it's been literally one. Tomorrow and Sunday, though, parts of Brooklyn will take on the look of a military campaign, with musket smoke as well as smog clogging the air, and booming cannons competing with the traffic noise. title: FAMILY FARE

body: SHOWING a degree of resilience in the face of the national economic slowdown, the residential real estate market in the New York metropolitan region clung to its penchant for price increases in the first half of the year, even as buyers became more choosy (or wary) and sellers lost a bit of their swagger. title: Home Prices Are Up, but Not as Much

body: Fred Wilpon became a New York real-estate plutocrat, the builder of tall towers along gilded blocks of Manhattan avenues, by excelling at the art of the calculated risk. title: The House That Rudy Built

title: Black Leaders May Be Near Endorsement Of Ferrer

body: Prison officials say that nearly 10,000 inmates in New York and thousands more across the country are infected with hepatitis C, an insidious liver infection that is difficult to treat, has no definite cure and, over many years, kills 5 percent of those who contract it. title: A Health Danger From a Needle Becomes a Scourge Behind Bars

title: Commercial Real Estate; Tight Retail Spaces Prompt Suit by the Disabled

title: BASEBALL; It's Summer: The Boys Are Back in Town

title: CUTTINGS; A Land Rush for Compost in the City

title: Court Upholds Conviction In Vote Fraud By Candidate

title: Searching for Charles

body: SOMETIME later today, the National Invitation Tournament committee will convene, as always on college basketball's annual day of destiny, to select the remains of the tournament-bound elite. And if there is still a heart beating inside a once-grand event that celebrates the Big Apple as the core of the sport, Ron Ganulin will answer the telephone
title: Sports of The Times; Rooting for St. Francis, an Unnatural Selection

body: The fate of the bill to repeal City Council term limits rests in the hands of a small, eclectic group of undecided Council members, several of whom openly admit that they consider a vote either way to be unappealing. They do not want to so brashly disregard the will of New York City voters, who twice have supported the two-term limit, first in 1993
title: Bill to Overturn Term Limits Comes Down to Undecideds

body: The police yesterday seized a small arsenal of high-powered weapons and Nazi memorabilia from a Brooklyn man after he was found in a park Wednesday firing a pistol at a picture of his girlfriend's mother, the authorities said. An off-duty police detective jogging Wednesday afternoon in Marine Park in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, heard the gunshots
title: Weapons and Nazi Artifacts Seized After Arrest

author: Mitch Abramson, who lives in Manhattan, has previously written about boxing for The New York Times.
body: Before Jill Emery took up boxing, she was an actress. Casting directors always used to tell her that she was a spitting image of Winona Ryder, with the same doe-eyed innocence and concerned smile. After she gave up show business a few years back, she found that such remarks were flattering but useless. Theatrics would not help her in the ring. The
title: PERSPECTIVE; The Ring's the Thing for a Former Actress

body: At Smith's Bar on 44th Street and Eighth Avenue on Tuesday night, the ironworkers were talking of little else. It had rained that morning, and then the rain turned to a light snow. A young steel connecter working in Midtown tried an old ironworker's trick: sliding down a column head first. He slipped, did a flip in the air and landed two floors
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; Iron in the Blood, Misfortune on the Mind

body: IT took two years of looking before Nicholas and Jill Benz Malter found a house. The couple, who had previously rented in Windsor Terrace and Park Slope in Brooklyn, settled on a two-story brick row house in Sunset Park, arriving in late summer with their 3-year-old son, Teddy. ''We wanted a nice house, something sturdy, with some historic
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sunset Park, Brooklyn; Historic Character and Foreign Accents

body: ON a recent winter afternoon, as the temperature dipped below freezing and a brisk wind blew along the cross streets of Midtown Manhattan, an ironworker named John Collins stepped out onto a six-inch-wide steel beam 24 stories above Seventh Avenue and started to walk across it. Mr. Collins carried 45 pounds of equipment on his belt, including two
title: Cowboys of the Sky

body: Alfred A. Allegretti, who transformed his father's one-truck oil dealership beside the Gowanus Canal into one of the largest heating oil companies in the New York metropolitan area, died Jan. 13 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 65 and lived in the Bay Ridge neighborhood of Brooklyn. The cause was prostate cancer, his
title: Alfred Allegretti, 65, Heating Oil Executive

title: Where the Belles of Brooklyn Shop

title: The Neediest Cases; Family Overcomes Illness and Job Loss

body: Four people returning from a New Year's Day party were killed early yesterday when their speeding car struck a City Sanitation Department front-loader clearing snow from the weekend storm, officials said. title: Four Killed as Car Strikes a Front-Loader Clearing Snow
